title: Tennis Legends
description: How well do you know the greatest tennis players and Grand Slam history?

questions.question: What are the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments?
options: US Open, French Open, Wimbledon, Canadian Open
US Open, French Open, Wimbledon, Indian Wells
US Open, French Open, Wimbledon, Australian Open
US Open, French Open, Wimbledon, Italian Open
questions.explanation: The four Grand Slam tournaments are the Australian Open, French Open (Roland Garros), Wimbledon, and US Open. They are the most prestigious events in tennis.

questions.question: Which male tennis player holds the record for most Grand Slam singles titles?
questions.explanation: Novak Djokovic holds the record for most Grand Slam singles titles with 24 as of 2024, surpassing Rafael Nadal's 22 and Roger Federer's 20.

questions.question: On what surface is Wimbledon played?
questions.explanation: Wimbledon is played on grass courts, making it the only Grand Slam tournament played on this surface. The tournament has been held at the All England Club since 1877.

questions.question: Which female tennis player won 23 Grand Slam singles titles?
questions.explanation: Serena Williams won 23 Grand Slam singles titles in the Open Era, the most by any player during this period. Margaret Court holds the all-time record with 24 (including pre-Open Era titles).

questions.question: What is a 'Grand Slam' in tennis (as an achievement)?
options: Winning a match without losing a set
Winning all four Grand Slam tournaments in one calendar year
questions.explanation: A Grand Slam in tennis means winning all four major tournaments (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, US Open) in the same calendar year. Only a handful of players have achieved this.

questions.question: Which tennis player was known as 'The Ice Man' for his calm demeanor?
questions.explanation: Bjorn Borg of Sweden was known as 'The Ice Man' or 'Ice-Borg' for his cool, unflappable demeanor on court. He won 11 Grand Slam titles and 6 consecutive French Opens.

questions.question: What is the scoring sequence in a tennis game?
questions.explanation: Tennis uses the scoring sequence love (0), 15, 30, 40, game. If both players reach 40, it is called 'deuce,' and a player must win by two consecutive points.

questions.question: Who was the first African American man to win a Grand Slam singles title?
questions.explanation: Arthur Ashe became the first African American man to win a Grand Slam singles title at the 1968 US Open. He also won the Australian Open (1970) and Wimbledon (1975).

questions.question: What is a 'tiebreak' in tennis?
options: A coin toss to decide the winner
An extra match to decide a draw
A special game played when a set is tied at 6-6
questions.explanation: A tiebreak is a special game played when a set reaches 6-6. Players alternate serves, and the first to reach 7 points (with a 2-point lead) wins the tiebreak and the set.

questions.question: Which Spanish player is known as 'The King of Clay'?
questions.explanation: Rafael Nadal is known as 'The King of Clay' for his dominance on clay courts, especially at the French Open where he won a record 14 titles.

questions.question: What was unique about the longest match in Wimbledon history between Isner and Mahut in 2010?
options: It lasted 11 hours 5 minutes over 3 days
questions.explanation: The 2010 Wimbledon match between John Isner and Nicolas Mahut lasted 11 hours 5 minutes over three days, with the final set ending 70-68 in Isner's favor. It remains the longest match in tennis history.

questions.question: What is an 'ace' in tennis?
options: Hitting a winner from the baseline
Winning a game without losing a point
A serve that the opponent cannot return
questions.explanation: An ace is a legal serve that the receiving player is unable to touch with their racket. It is an outright point for the server.

questions.question: Which female player achieved the Calendar Year Grand Slam in 1988?
questions.explanation: Steffi Graf won all four Grand Slam titles and the Olympic gold medal in 1988, achieving what is called the 'Golden Slam' â€” the only player ever to do so in a single calendar year.

questions.question: What surface is the French Open played on?
questions.explanation: The French Open (Roland Garros) is played on red clay courts. The slower surface favors baseline players with heavy topspin and stamina.

questions.question: Which twins both reached world No. 1 in doubles tennis?
questions.explanation: Bob and Mike Bryan, identical twins from the United States, became the most successful doubles team in tennis history, winning 16 Grand Slam men's doubles titles together.
